LBOMETR Course Book 1 Introduction 1.1 About Me

LBOMETR Course Book Jem Marie M. Nario 2026-01-02 1 Introduction Welcome to the LBOMETR Course Book! This book is designed to guide students through the course by providing all necessary resources, materials, and instructions. LBOMETR This course book is intended to ensure that DLSU Carlos L. Tiu-School of Economics students will be able to learn more about Econometrics using R. You will find sections on the syllabus, course assessments, and group projects, as well as guidance for navigating the course effectively. 1.1 About Me My name is Jem Marie M. Nario, and I am your lecturer for this course. I am excited to guide you through this journey of learning and discovery since I am also on a journey of learning and discovery while teaching part-time. This book is a trial version whnb ich will be updated along the course as it also serves as a practice for me. Email: jem.nario@dlsu.edu.ph LinkedIn: linkedin.com/in/jmnario/ Feel free to reach out with any questions or concerns throughout the course.

2 Syllabus 2.1 Course Information 2.2 Learning Goals and Outcomes 2.3 Mapping of CLOs to ELGAs 2.4 Mapping of CLOs to PLOs 2.5 Course Assessments 2.6 Grading System 2.7 Class Policies

2 Syllabus You can download the course syllabus using the link in an announcement. 2.1 Course Information 2.1.1 General Course Description This course introduces Economics majors to more advanced commands and techniques used in the econometric software package R, commonly used in empirical research. 2.1.2 Specific Course Description This course familiarizes Economics majors with advanced techniques in R for empirical research. Students will gather and analyze their own real-world data to investigate a specific economic problem, applying econometric methods and presenting their findings in a final project. 2.2 Learning Goals and Outcomes 2.2.1 Expected Lasallian Graduate Attributes (ELGAs) Culturally Sensitive, Critical, and Creative Thinkers Effective Communicator Reflective Lifelong Learner and Competitive Self-Nurturer Engaged and Service-Driven Citizen Virtue-Guided Decision-Maker Technically Proficient Professional 2.2.2 Programme Learning Outcomes (PLOs) 2.2.2.1 Pre-Major (Theorising) Describe key facts and issues about the Philippine and ASEAN+X economies, and explain how basic indicators are formulated Use tables, graphs, algebra, and calculus as primary analytical tools Transition from high school work and habits to become avid readers, clear writers, and quick synthesisers of college-level material Consistently exhibit self-regulation, valuing other people’s time 2.2.2.2 Major (Solving) Analyse the workings and history of key markets and institutions using current economic models Implement the scientific method on economic problems: developing hypotheses, envisioning data requirements, analysing with mathematical and statistical tools Adapt to new situations and respond maturely to setbacks Consistently work well with others, participate in multidisciplinary discussions with an open mind and respect for others’ views 2.2.2.3 Capstone (Translating) Evaluate market policies and decisions using key economic principles, particularly opportunity-cost, marginal, and positive-sum thinking Create short-form and long-form research that analyses real-world issues and incorporates knowledge from other disciplines Communicate sensibly and sensitively with different audiences Synthesise and exhibit what it means to be a Lasallian economist, to bridge faith and scholarship 2.2.3 Course Learning Outcomes (CLOs) 2.2.3.1 Knowledge Distinguish a theoretical economic model from a statistical econometric model Use the R software package in estimating advanced econometric models Learn advanced econometric models to explore new methods of research 2.2.3.2 Skills Apply numerical and statistical techniques in economic analysis Use statistical concepts as a language in economic discourse Confidently write script files for economic analysis 2.2.3.3 Behavior/Attitude Demonstrate transparency and academic integrity in handling data analysis Construct more complex programs from basic commands learned in class 2.3 Mapping of CLOs to ELGAs CLOs ELGA1 ELGA2 ELGA3 ELGA4 ELGA5 ELGA6 CLO1 ✔ CLO2 ✔ ✔ ✔ CLO3 ✔ ✔ ✔ CLO4 ✔ ✔ CLO5 ✔ ✔ ✔ CLO6 ✔ ✔ ✔ CLO7 ✔ ✔ ✔ CLO8 ✔ ✔ ✔ 2.4 Mapping of CLOs to PLOs CLOs PLO1 PLO2 PLO3 PLO4 PLO5 PLO6 PLO7 PLO8 PLO9 PLO10 PLO11 PLO12 CLO1 ✔ ✔ CLO2 ✔ ✔ CLO3 ✔ ✔ ✔ ✔ ✔ CLO4 ✔ ✔ ✔ CLO5 ✔ ✔ ✔ ✔ CLO6 ✔ ✔ ✔ CLO7 ✔ ✔ ✔ ✔ CLO8 ✔ ✔ ✔ ✔ ✔ 2.5 Course Assessments CLOs Assessment Week (Due Date) 1, 2, 6, 8 Interactive Coding Check Weekly 1, 3, 6, 7, 8 Midway Practical Check + Peer Evaluation Week 7 1, 2, 3, 5, 7 Data Story Presentation Week 10 1, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8 Data Story Archive Week 13 2.6 Grading System Component Weight Interactive Coding Check (Attendance) 5% Midway Practical Check + Peer Evaluation 10% Data Story Presentation 35% Data Story Archive 50% Total 100% 2.7 Class Policies 2.7.1 1. Attendance Attendance will be checked at random times during class and counts for 5% of the final grade. For each unexcused absence, 0.6 points will be deducted. Excused absences (with valid documentation) will not incur deductions (see Appendix). 2.7.2 2. Course Materials All materials related to LBOMETR will be made available through AnimoSpace. Improper use, reproduction, or distribution of LBOMETR learning and teaching materials constitutes a violation of academic integrity and will be reported to the Discipline Office. 2.7.3 3. Grading Notes Achieving a perfect score (100%) in this course is extremely difficult. Even excellent students typically achieve a maximum of around 95%. Grades are strictly based on demonstrated mastery, output quality, and adherence to course rubrics. 2.7.4 4. Incentives and Extra Credit No general incentives will be provided in this class. However, an optional extra credit assignment is available: Students may submit a 5-minute vlog explaining a chosen lab econometrics method and how they intend to apply it in real-world research. Successful submission will earn an additional 0.3 points added to the final raw grade. The vlog must be submitted by email only, no later than August 8, 21:00. Details are outlined in the Other Requirements or Activities section. 2.7.5 5. Computer Practicals a. Group Participation - Computer Practicals must be completed in groups. - Every group member is required to participate and contribute at least once during class activities. - Non-participation may result in deductions from the Group Participation grade. b. Weekly Submission - Practicals are not graded weekly. - All completed practicals must be compiled and submitted as an appendix to the Data Story Archive. c. Midway Check - A midway practical check will ensure steady progress. - Each group must show evidence that at least 50% of practicals have been completed and stored (e.g., Quarto files, datasets, meeting notes). - Incomplete work may result in deductions from both the Group Participation grade and other assessments. 2.7.6 6. Groupings and Peer Evaluation a. Group Formation - Groups (4–5 members) will be randomly assigned based on a survey conducted in the first meeting. b. Peer Evaluation Two evaluations will be conducted: Midway Evaluation (Week 7): Peer assessment via anonymous Google Form. Students scoring below the class median will receive a warning email. Final Evaluation (after project submission): Students scoring below the median in either or both evaluations will face deductions from their Group Participation and possibly other assessment grades. 2.7.7 7. Extensions No extensions will be granted. There are only two major deadlines in this course—students are expected to manage their time accordingly. 2.7.8 8. Use of AI Tools A full AI Use Policy is provided in the Appendix. In brief: AI tools (e.g., ChatGPT) are allowed only for coding assistance (e.g., debugging). Students must acknowledge AI use in their submissions. Students must critically review and verify all AI outputs. AI-generated content or unchecked code must not be submitted as final work. 2.7.9 9. Consultations a. Data Story Topic Submission - Submit topic via email by May 23, 2025, at 21:00. - Subject line format: LBOMETR [Section] – Group No. – Data Story Topic. - In the email body: describe the topic, explain why it was chosen, and list expected data sources. - Topic changes must be made in the same email thread. - No changes allowed after Week 6. - Unauthorized changes beyond Week 6 will result in a 50% deduction from the Data Story and related grades. b. Mock Presentations - No live mock presentations due to a conference from June 23–27. - Groups must submit recorded mock presentations: - Monday groups: by Friday, June 20, 2025, at 21:00. - Thursday groups: by Tuesday, June 24, 2025, at 21:00. - Recordings must be clear, professional, and reflect the intended structure of the final presentation. c. Data Story Archive Consultations - After mock submissions, groups are encouraged to book 15-minute consultations to improve their archives. - Booking link will be provided. d. Other Consultations - For other concerns, email the professor. - If there’s no reply within 3 days, send a polite follow-up email. e. Final Presentation Venue - A HyFlex classroom will be used for the final presentation. - Groups must prepare to present to both in-person and online audiences.
course-assessments-1.html
3 Course Assessments 3.1 Data Story Archive 3.2 Data Story Presentation

3 Course Assessments 3.1 Data Story Archive The Data Story Archive is the culmination of your group’s work throughout the course. It includes your group’s data story report, R script, practical assignments, and a group reflection, all compiled into a single professionally formatted PDF file. 3.1.1 Requirements Your submission should follow this structure: Cover Page: Include the title of the Data Story, group members, and submission date. Table of Contents: Provide a clear list of sections with page numbers. Data Story Report: The complete report should include: Introduction: Problem statement and research question. Methods: Data sources, methodology, and analysis techniques. Results: Key findings supported by R-generated visuals. Discussion: Implications of the findings and any limitations. Conclusion: Summary and recommendations. Appendix: Supporting tables, additional plots, or materials. R Script: Render your R script as an HTML using Quarto Markdown. Ensure the script is well-structured, commented, and includes outputs like plots and tables. Computer Practicals: Include PDFs of all Quarto Markdown files from your computer practicals by printing the html as pdf. Group Reflection: Write a 1-2 page reflection on: Your teamwork experience (challenges and successes). What you learned from working on the data story. How the course contributed to your growth in data analysis and collaboration. 3.1.2 Submission Combine all the components into a single PDF file. Name your file as: LBOMETR[Section_GroupNo.]_DataStoryArchive.pdf Deadline: [4 August 2025, 21:00]. In the event that the file is too big for Animospace, kindly submit as pdf to my email. 3.1.3 Grading Rubric for Data Story Archive The grading rubric for the Data Story Archive is divided into three categories: Content, Analysis and Technical Work, and Overall Presentation Quality. ### Evaluation Rubric Criteria Exemplary (≥ 90) Satisfactory (78–89) Developing (72–77) Beginning (< 72) Points Content All parts are fully achieved, with the problem clearly stated; the report is comprehensive and well-written; the appendix is complete and organized Most parts are well-done, but there may be minor gaps in clarity, writing depth, or appendix completeness Only some parts are well done; the problem is somewhat vague; the report may be incomplete or unclear Major issues across all areas 35 Analysis and Technical Work R scripts, practicals, and visualizations are technically excellent, reproducible, fully documented, error-free, and insightful Technical work is generally correct but may have minor reproducibility or clarity issues Scripts and practicals are partially complete or have several errors; visualizations may lack clarity or polish Technical work is largely incomplete, difficult to reproduce, with poor or missing visualizations 45 Overall Presentation Quality Reflection is deep and thoughtful; organization is professional and consistent throughout the archive Reflection and organization are acceptable but may have minor areas for improvement Reflection is superficial or incomplete; archive organization is inconsistent or confusing Reflection is missing or meaningless; archive is poorly organized and difficult to navigate 20 Total 100% 3.2 Data Story Presentation The Data Story Presentation is your group’s opportunity to communicate your findings and insights through a live presentation. This format allows you to showcase animated visualizations and engage directly with the audience in real time. A room will be requested for you to be able to present in front of your classmates and I will be present online; 3.2.1 Requirements Objective: Your live presentation should effectively communicate your data story with clarity, engagement, and professionalism, making full use of visuals and animations to enhance understanding. Presentation Structure: The presentation must include the following sections: Introduction: Briefly introduce your topic, research question, and the significance of your data story (1 slide). Methods: Provide a concise explanation of your data and analysis methodology (1-2 slides). Results: Highlight the most important findings using R-generated visualizations, including animations if applicable (3-4 slides). Discussion and Conclusion: Discuss the implications of your findings and conclude with actionable insights or recommendations (1 slide). Delivery: Each group member must actively participate in the presentation. Presentation duration: 10 minutes, followed by a 5-minute Q&A session. Visualizations: Use animated or interactive visualizations (e.g., created with gganimate or other R packages) to effectively demonstrate key trends and insights. Ensure visuals are clear, professional, and aligned with your narrative. Tools: Create your presentation using tools like Google Slides, Microsoft PowerPoint, or Canva. Incorporate animated visualizations as needed. Submission: Submit your presentation slides as a PDF file named: LBOMETR[Section_GroupNo.]_DataStoryPresentation.pdf Submit the file before your scheduled presentation time. 3.2.2 Grading Rubric The grading rubric for the Data Story Presentation is divided into three categories: Content, Visualizations, and Delivery and Engagement. ### Presentation Rubric Criteria Exemplary (≥ 90) Satisfactory (78–89) Developing (72–77) Beginning (< 72) Points Content The introduction and methods are very clear, concise, and logically presented. Results are detailed and highlight key findings effectively. Discussion and conclusions are insightful and offer actionable recommendations. The introduction and methods are clear but may lack some conciseness. Results are logical but may miss highlighting deeper insights. Discussion and conclusions are solid but could be more actionable. The introduction and methods are somewhat vague or rushed. Results are presented but may lack depth or logical flow. Discussion and conclusions are simplistic or partially missing. The introduction, methods, and results are poorly developed or unclear. Major parts of the discussion and conclusions are missing or irrelevant. 40 Visualizations Visuals are professional, highly polished, and strongly enhance understanding. Appropriate animations or dynamic elements are used skillfully. Visuals are generally appropriate and support the analysis, but could be improved in design or relevance. Minor flaws or missed opportunities for better storytelling. Visuals are present but are basic, poorly designed, or only loosely connected to the analysis. Important visual aids may be missing. Visuals are missing, poorly designed, or irrelevant to the analysis. Presentation lacks proper visual support entirely. 30 Delivery/Engagement The group presents with full confidence, clarity, and professionalism. They creatively engage the audience, respond to questions effectively, and strictly adhere to the time limit. Delivery is confident but may have minor lapses in clarity or pacing. Audience engagement is adequate but not very dynamic. Time management is acceptable with minor deviations. Delivery shows noticeable gaps in confidence or clarity. Audience engagement is weak. Time management is problematic (either too short or overrunning time limits). Delivery is unclear, unconfident, or disorganized. Little to no audience engagement. Severe issues with time management. 30 Total 100%
grouping-process.html
4 Grouping Process 4.1 How Groups Are Formed 4.2 Announcement of Groups

4 Grouping Process Students will be randomly assigned to groups of 4-5 members based on their responses to a pre-course survey. The survey collects information that will be used to ensure fair and balanced groupings. The group assignments will be announced on the first day of the course. 4.1 How Groups Are Formed The groupings are created using RStudio. The coding ensures randomness while incorporating some aspects of the survey responses to balance groups. If you wish to see the code used for grouping, you may contact me directly. However, please note: - The CSV file with survey responses will not be shared to protect your anonymity and privacy. 4.2 Announcement of Groups The group assignments will be distributed on the first day of the course. Please check your assigned group and connect with your group members as soon as possible.
data-story-research-question.html
5 Data Story Research Question 5.1 Guidelines in Conducting Data Story 5.2 Comments on Research Questions:

5 Data Story Research Question 5.1 Guidelines in Conducting Data Story 5.1.1 Research Question: In writing your Research Question, you should keep in mind the following acronym: S-M-A-R-T S-Specific M-Measurable A-Achievable R-Relevant T-Time-bound What do you think of this research question: “What is the effect of X(Twitter) on mental health?“ Do you think this question is SMART? How about this question: “What is the relationship between hours spent per day on X/Twitter and reported levels of anxiety among undergraduate students in DLSU during 2020-2021?“ Which of the two achieves the SMART elements? 5.1.2 Relevance What will be asked by the audience? You need to ask yourselves the following questions; if you are able to, you are close to achieving a good presentation! What is the problem to be solved? Who cares about this problem and why? 5.1.3 For the data story, should I use Kaggle? The answer is NO because of the following reasons: It has already been cleaned and curated based on the owner’s own purposes. It may not accurately reflect the real-world data. It has limited context, potentially limiting your ability to interpret findings accurately. While some Kaggle datasets have clear sources, others may have unclear origins or have undergone modifications by multiple users raising concerns about data integrity. Thus, you should use credible sources like statistics from World Bank, government sites, etc. I am not saying that you can already drop Kaggle datasets. You can still use them for the following: Benchmarking: Compare your model on a well-known Kaggle dataset For learning: You can try to match how the datasets in Kaggle have been cleaned. You can also use the datasets to practice your codes before applying them to the data you found from other credible sources. Important to note: Check data documentation from Kaggle; this will help you find the sources and will help supplement your data story with reputable sources. Furthermore, this is LBOMETR class wherein you were taught how to clean a dataset. You have to gather and clean the data yourselves to align with your research question. 5.2 Comments on Research Questions: Please check your emails for comments regarding your research questions. The approved and final research questions will be posted in Animospace as an announcement.
basic-introduction-to-r.html
6 Basic Introduction to R 6.1 Session Information 6.2 Preliminaries 6.3 Quarto Markdown 6.4 Packages 6.5 Instructions for Managing Working Directories 6.6 Note:

6 Basic Introduction to R This portion of the book offers an introduction to the basics of R. R offers a wide variety of functionality. Note that this book only offers basic Econometric analysis. It will be useful to have some basic familiarity with R and its syntax but this is not strictly necessary. Each chapter includes both R code and results to make it easier for students to follow along, even without detailed knowledge of R. 6.1 Session Information This version of the book was built using R version 4.4.2. See below for the session information: ## R version 4.5.2 (2025-10-31 ucrt) ## Platform: x86_64-w64-mingw32/x64 ## Running under: Windows 11 x64 (build 26100) ## ## Matrix products: default ## LAPACK version 3.12.1 ## ## locale: ## [1] LC_COLLATE=English_Netherlands.utf8 LC_CTYPE=English_Netherlands.utf8 ## [3] LC_MONETARY=English_Netherlands.utf8 LC_NUMERIC=C ## [5] LC_TIME=English_Netherlands.utf8 ## ## time zone: Asia/Manila ## tzcode source: internal ## ## attached base packages: ## [1] stats graphics grDevices utils datasets methods base ## ## other attached packages: ## [1] bookdown_0.46 ## ## loaded via a namespace (and not attached): ## [1] digest_0.6.39 R6_2.6.1 fastmap_1.2.0 xfun_0.55 cachem_1.1.0 ## [6] knitr_1.51 htmltools_0.5.9 rmarkdown_2.30 tinytex_0.58 lifecycle_1.0.4 ## [11] cli_3.6.5 sass_0.4.10 jquerylib_0.1.4 compiler_4.5.2 rstudioapi_0.17.1 ## [16] tools_4.5.2 evaluate_1.0.5 bslib_0.9.0 yaml_2.3.12 jsonlite_2.0.0 ## [21] rlang_1.1.6 6.2 Preliminaries The first step is to gain access to R, which is free and available on the R website: http://cran.r-project.org/. Simply go to the R website, select the appropriate location and operating system, and follow the instructions to download the base distribution of R. RStudio offers a user friendly environment to run R and is recommended. RStudio Screen Once R is opened, we can begin to run commands. R commands can be run directly from the console, from the R script editor or from a text editor separate from R. R offers detailed help files for each function. To access help, run: ?sum All lines proceeded by a # are comments and will not run. For example: # This is a comment. R will not recognize this as a command. 6.3 Quarto Markdown In LBOMETR, Quarto Markdown will be used by the students when submitting the Scripts for the Data Story Archive. Quarto Markdown is a tool for creating documents, reports and presentations using Markdown and executable code. Below is a concise guide to help you get started, along with key shortcuts for both Mac and Windows. 6.3.1 1. Starting a Quarto File To begin creating a Quarto document, follow these steps: Open RStudio. Go to File > New File > Quarto Document. Choose the document type (e.g., HTML, PDF, Word, etc.) and specify whether the document will include code. For ease, we will use the html document type. I have also added a sample Quarto Markdown file you can copy. Quarto Markdown Template 2. Quarto Key Features Code Chunks Code chunks allow you to include and run code inside your document. Inline Code Embed R code in text using backticks and r . Quarto Markdown Shortcuts Action Windows Shortcut Mac Shortcut Insert a new code chunk Ctrl+Alt+I Cmd+Alt+I Run current code chunk Ctrl+Shift+Enter Cmd+Shift+Enter Run all code chunks Ctrl+Alt+R Cmd+Alt+R Run current line/selection Ctrl+Enter Cmd+Enter Knit/Render document Ctrl+Shift+K Cmd+Shift+K Comment/uncomment lines Ctrl+Shift+C Cmd+Shift+C Insert pipe (%>%) Ctrl+Shift+M Cmd+Shift+M Headings /Number of Heading (if in Visual mode) Prefix line with #, ##, etc. manually (in Source mode) /Number of Heading (if in Visual mode) Prefix line with #, ##, etc. manually (in Source mode) Bold Ctrl+B Cmd+B Italic Ctrl+I Cmd+I Inline code Surround with backticks (’) manually Surround with backticks (’) manually *Note: you can choose between Source or Visual (upper left); personally, it is easier for me to use the Visual Mode compared to the Source Mode. 6.4 Packages Each package of interest must be installed and loaded before it can be used. The packages will not be immediately available when R is opened. A package only has to be installed once on a computer, but the package will have to be loaded every time R is restarted. We can install a package individually as we need them. For example, to install tidyverse and psych, we would do: install.packages("tidyverse") install.packages("psych") In the tidyverse package, the ggplot2 is usually included; if you do not see the package in the Packages list at the lower right, you can do this: if(!("ggplot2" %in% installed.packages()[,"Package"])) install.packages("ggplot2") Now that we have our packages successfully installed, we can go ahead and load them into R. Here we will load the tidyverse package as an example. We can use of all the functions available in that package once it is loaded into R. We load packages by using a library() function. The input is the name of the package, not in quotes. library(tidyverse) We can look up all of the functions within a package by using a help() function. For example, let’s look at the functions available in the tidyverse package. help(package = tidyverse) Note that the package argument is necessary to look up all of the functions. We can also detach a package if we no longer want it loaded. This is sometimes useful if two packages do not play well together. Here we will use a detach() function. detach(package:tidyverse) For simplicity, we will assume that the reader has restarted R at the beginning of each tutorial. 6.5 Instructions for Managing Working Directories This guide outlines how team members should set up their local working directories for collaboration, handle .qmd files, and organize them in a shared Google Drive. 6.5.1 1. Local Working Directory Setup Each team member should create a local folder on their own laptops to work on qmd files. This folder is where you will store and edit your files before uploading them to the shared Google Drive. 6.5.1.1 Steps: Create a folder on your laptop named: DLSU_LBOMETR_Section Use this folder to save and organize your .qmd files while working locally. 6.5.2 2. File Naming Convention To avoid confusion, ensure all .qmd files are named as follows: Include your name or initials and a brief description of the content Example: jem_nario_descriptivestatistics.qmd jmn_piechart.qmd 6.5.3 3. Shared Google Drive Setup A shared Google Drive will serve as the central repository for all project files, including: .qmd files from all team members Data files Rendered HTML and PDF files for final submission Supporting documents or references. 6.5.4 4. Workflow for .qmd files For each team member: Work locally Create your .qmd file in your local DLSU_LBOMETR_Section folder Ensure it is well-documented and organized. Upload to Google Drive For the Team Leader: Collect and Combine Files Gather all .qmd files from the team folder on the shared drive. Combine them Render the final report 6.5.5 5. Rendering the Final Report The final report should be rendered in HTML and printed by the team leader. 6.5.6 Summary Workflow Each Team Member: Work on your .qmd file locally. Upload your file to the shared Google Drive under team-members-qmd. Team Leader: Collect .qmd files from the shared drive. Combine them into a single final_report.qmd. Render the final report into HTML and PDF. Upload the rendered files to the final-report folder on the shared Google Drive. This ensures an organized and efficient workflow while centralizing all files in the shared Google Drive for easy access and submission. 6.6 Note: For the next chapters, before coming to class, ensure that you have installed the necessary packages. Therefore, please go to the next chapters of the course book then Find codes that have install.packages. Please install all the packages so that you will not have any issues.
